The Livingstone Expedition

In November 2014 Jack Wrigley and Angus Aitken plan to recreate Dr David Livingstone’s trans African trek on the 160th anniversary of the original expedition. They will set out from Luanda in Angola in early November and reach Quelimane in Mozambique seven months later. The total distance is approximately 5000km. The expedition will be conducted entirely by means which would have been available to Livingstone – by animal, on foot and by dug out canoe.

More Info
The Voyage of the Nkhwazi

'The Voyage of the Nkhwazi' is the second expedition undertaken by Jack and Angus. They travelled to Lake Malawi, first revealed to European eyes in 1846 and later explored by David Livingstone in 1859, the 3rd largest lake in Africa. They commissioned the construction of a local wooden fishing boat - the HMS Nkhwazi and set course to travel the length of the lake with Charles a Malawian who would act as a local guide and friend. They rowed and sailed up the Eastern Coast of the lake encountering some of the most isolated fishing communities in Africa. Their adventure saw them battle storms, hippos and local border guards convinced that they were spies. A film of the trip is currently in post-production stage.

More Info
A Journey with Nomads

'Blue Horizons: a Journey with Nomads' follows Jack Wrigley and Angus Aitken, two friends from school days, on their adventure through Outer Mongolia. They travelled 1000 miles on horseback and then by camel living and staying with nomads along the way. Their journey takes them from pine forested uplands in the north to vast swathes of Gobi desert in the south. The film documents their 2 month expedition but also reflects upon the way of life of the nomads whom they were so dependent upon. During their wandering the two friends encounter the direct impact that the opening up of Mongolia for its natural resources has had on nomads' way of life.
